CATHAY HOTEL
SHANGHAI
CHINA
FEB. 27, 1933
Dear Mr. Ball;
I promised you several days ago that I would write to you fully re
my converaation with Carl Nahrmacher. He is a young man of about thirty three
years of age. He runs a garage to eat and sells, or tries to sell, air planes
102et 04.
agent under Gale and Company of this city, who are the recognized outlet
United Aviation products in China. He also represents Fleet of Buffalo, and
claims to have sold about thirty training planes to the hinese Government at
Nanking.
These are the planes being used
by the American Aviation Mission at
Hangchow for the purpose of training Chinese Pilots. Nahunacher has another
young fellow with him by the name of Lewis who is also a pilot. There is no
recognized civil aviation in China, no licenses are iasued for commercial or
private flying. Apparently both Nahmmacher and Lewis have done a good deal. of
barnstorming work by air all with a view of selling military, rather than
private, aircraft. He does not think there is any mrket over here for
a good line of conversation - plenty of it - has lived over here long enough
to know his way around, and is reported financially responsible within sone-
what restricted bounds.
Men who have lived over here for forty years frankly admit that they
do not know a bit more than when they came here, so you cant expect much from
a man who has been here two weelts.
There are a number of things with respect
however,
which I am willing to write about. First, as I said be-
fore there is no civil aviation. Landing fields are a long way apart, and you
would not have that picture of two crashes and a question mark hanging on the
wall if the crackups had been over here. Your widow might have the first one.
Almost every inch of ground is taken up with rice fields - the Chinese pro-
nounce "rice" "lice" and well they might when it somes to a forced landing,
with a ditch well dyked with a wall of
